<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="100%"> <P STYLE=" margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt; font-size:7pt; font-family:ARIAL">Form W-9 (Rev. <FONT STYLE="white-space:nowrap">11-2017)</FONT> </P></TD>
<TD> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt; font-size:7pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="right">Page&nbsp;<FONT STYLE="font-size:10pt"><B>4</B></FONT> </P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="line-height:4.0pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:2pt;border-bottom:1.00pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P>
<p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; width:48%;padding-right:0%;padding-bottom:8pt;overflow:hidden;padding-top:3pt">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">The following chart shows types of payments that may be exempt from backup withholding. The chart applies
to the exempt payees listed above, 1 through 13. </P> <P STYLE="font-size:4pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:8pt" ALIGN="center">


<TR>
<TD WIDTH="48%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="4%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="48%"></TD></TR>


<TR STYLE="page-break-inside:avoid ; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:8pt">
<TD VALIGN="top" NOWRAP STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1.00pt solid #000000; BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt"><B>IF the payment is for&nbsp;.&nbsp;.&nbsp;.</B></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE=" BORDER-TOP:1.00pt solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" NOWRAP STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1.00pt solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><B>THEN the payment is exempt for&nbsp;.&nbsp;.&nbsp;.</B></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="page-break-inside:avoid ; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:8pt">
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">Interest and dividend payments</P>
<P STYLE="font-size:2pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt">&nbsp;</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE=" BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">All exempt payees except for 7</P>
<P STYLE="font-size:2pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="page-break-inside:avoid ; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:8pt">
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt">Broker transactions</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE=" BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">Exempt payees 1 through 4 and 6 through 11 and all C corporations. S corporations must not enter an exempt
payee code because they are exempt only for sales of noncovered securities acquired prior to 2012.</P> <P STYLE="font-size:2pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="page-break-inside:avoid ; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:8pt">
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">Barter exchange transactions and patronage dividends</P>
<P STYLE="font-size:2pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt">&nbsp;</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE=" BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">Exempt payees 1 through 4</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="page-break-inside:avoid ; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:8pt">
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">Payments over $600 required to be reported and direct sales
over $5,000<SUP STYLE="font-size:85%; vertical-align:top">1</SUP></P> <P STYLE="font-size:2pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt">&nbsp;</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE=" BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">Generally, exempt payees 1 through 5<SUP STYLE="font-size:85%; vertical-align:top">2</SUP></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="page-break-inside:avoid ; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:8pt">
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00pt solid #000000; padding-left:8pt"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">Payments made in settlement of payment card or third party
network transactions</P> <P STYLE="font-size:2pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt">&nbsp;</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE=" BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00pt solid #000000">Exempt payees 1 through 4</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:4pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:8pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR style = "page-break-inside:avoid">
<TD WIDTH="6" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><SUP STYLE="font-size:85%; vertical-align:top">1</SUP>&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">See Form 1099-MISC, Miscellaneous Income, and its instructions. </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:8pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR style = "page-break-inside:avoid">
<TD WIDTH="6" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><SUP STYLE="font-size:85%; vertical-align:top">2</SUP>&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">However, the following payments made to a corporation and reportable on Form&nbsp;1099-MISC are not exempt from backup withholding: medical and health care payments, attorneys&#146; fees, gross proceeds paid to an
attorney reportable under section 6045(f), and payments for services paid by a federal executive agency. </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Exemption from FATCA reporting code.</B>
The following codes identify payees that are exempt from reporting under FATCA. These codes apply to persons submitting this form for accounts maintained outside of the United States by certain foreign financial institutions. Therefore, if you are
only submitting this form for an account you hold in the United States, you may leave this field blank. Consult with the person requesting this form if you are uncertain if the financial institution is subject to these requirements. A requester may
indicate that a code is not required by providing you with a Form W-9 with &#147;Not Applicable&#148; (or any similar indication) written or printed on the line for a FATCA exemption code. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">A&#151;An organization exempt from tax under section 501(a) or any individual retirement plan as defined in section 7701(a)(37) </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">B&#151;The United States or any of its agencies or instrumentalities </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">C&#151;A state, the District of Columbia, a U.S. commonwealth or possession, or any of their political subdivisions or instrumentalities </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">D&#151;A corporation the stock of which is regularly traded on one or more established securities markets, as described in Regulations section
1.1472-1(c)(1)(i) </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">E&#151;A corporation that is a member of the same expanded affiliated group as a corporation described in Regulations section
1.1472-1(c)(1)(i) </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">F&#151;A dealer in securities, commodities, or derivative financial instruments (including notional principal contracts, futures,
forwards, and options) that is registered as such under the laws of the United States or any state </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">G&#151;A real estate investment trust </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">H&#151;A regulated investment company as defined in section 851 or an entity registered at all times during the tax year under the Investment Company Act
of 1940 </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">I&#151;A common trust fund as defined in section 584(a) </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">J&#151;A bank as defined in section 581 </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">K&#151;A
broker </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">L&#151;A trust exempt from tax under section 664 or described in section 4947(a)(1) </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">M&#151;A tax exempt trust under a section 403(b) plan or section 457(g) plan
</P></DIV><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; margin-left:3%; width:49%;padding-right:0%;padding-bottom:8pt;overflow:hidden;padding-top:3pt">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Note:</B> You may wish to consult with the financial institution requesting this form to determine whether the FATCA
code and/or exempt payee code should be completed. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:4pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Line 5 </B></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">Enter your
address (number, street, and apartment or suite number). This is where the requester of this Form W-9 will mail your information returns. If this address differs from the one the requester already has on file, write NEW at the top. If a new address
is provided, there is still a chance the old address will be used until the payor changes your address in their records. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:4pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Line 6 </B></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">Enter your city, state, and ZIP code. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:4pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Part I. Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN)
</B></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Enter your TIN in the appropriate box.</B> If you are a resident alien and you do not have and are not eligible to get an SSN, your TIN is your IRS individual
taxpayer identification number (ITIN). Enter it in the social security number box. If you do not have an ITIN, see How to get a <I>TIN</I> below. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:4pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">If
you are a sole proprietor and you have an EIN, you may enter either your SSN or EIN. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">If you are a single-member LLC that is disregarded as an entity
separate from its owner, enter the owner&#146;s SSN (or EIN, if the owner has one). Do not enter the disregarded entity&#146;s EIN. If the LLC is classified as a corporation or partnership, enter the entity&#146;s EIN. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Note:</B> See <I>What Name and Number To Give the Requester,</I> later, for further clarification of name and TIN combinations. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>How to get a TIN.</B> If you do not have a TIN, apply for one immediately. To apply for an SSN, get Form SS-5, Application for a Social Security Card, from your local
SSA office or get this form online at <I>www.SSA.gov.</I> You may also get this form by calling 1-800-772-1213. Use Form W-7, Application for IRS Individual Taxpayer Identification Number, to apply for an ITIN, or Form SS-4, Application for Employer
Identification Number, to apply for an EIN. You can apply for an EIN online by accessing the IRS website at <I>www.irs.gov/Businesses</I> and clicking on Employer Identification Number (EIN) under Starting a Business. Go to <I>www.irs.gov/Forms</I>
to view, download, or print Form W-7 and/or Form SS-4. Or, you can go to <I>www.irs.gov/OrderForms</I> to place an order and have Form W-7 and/or SS-4 mailed to you within 10 business days. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">If you are asked to complete Form W-9 but do not have a TIN, apply for a TIN and write &#147;Applied For&#148; in the space for the TIN, sign and date the
form, and give it to the requester. For interest and dividend payments, and certain payments made with respect to readily tradable instruments, generally you will have 60 days to get a TIN and give it to the requester before you are subject to
backup withholding on payments. The 60-day rule does not apply to other types of payments. You will be subject to backup withholding on all such payments until you provide your TIN to the requester. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Note:</B> Entering &#147;Applied For&#148; means that you have already applied for a TIN or that you intend to apply for one soon. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Caution:</B> A disregarded U.S. entity that has a foreign owner must use the appropriate Form W-8. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:4pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Part II. Certification </B></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">To establish to the withholding agent that you are a
U.S. person, or resident alien, sign Form W-9. You may be requested to sign by the withholding agent even if item 1, 4, or 5 below indicates otherwise. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">For a joint account, only the person whose TIN is shown in Part I should sign (when required). In the case of a disregarded entity, the person identified
on line 1 must sign. Exempt payees, see <I>Exempt payee code</I>, earlier. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Signature requirements.</B> Complete the certification as indicated in items 1 through
5 below. </P></div><div style="clear:both; height:0pt; font-size:0pt">&nbsp;</div>

</DIV></Center>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


<Center><DIV STYLE="width:8.5in" align="left">

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:7pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="100%"> <P STYLE=" margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt; font-size:7pt; font-family:ARIAL">Form W-9 (Rev. <FONT STYLE="white-space:nowrap">11-2017)</FONT> </P></TD>
<TD> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt; font-size:7pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="right">Page&nbsp;<FONT STYLE="font-size:10pt"><B>5</B></FONT> </P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="line-height:4.0pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:2pt;border-bottom:1.00pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P>
<p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; width:48%;padding-right:0%;padding-bottom:8pt;overflow:hidden;padding-top:3pt">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>1. Interest, dividend, and barter exchange accounts opened before 1984 and broker accounts considered
active during 1983.</B> You must give your correct TIN, but you do not have to sign the certification. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>2. Interest, dividend, broker, and barter
exchange accounts opened after 1983 and broker accounts considered inactive during 1983.</B> You must sign the certification or backup withholding will apply. If you are subject to backup withholding and you are merely providing your correct TIN to
the requester, you must cross out item 2 in the certification before signing the form. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>3. Real estate transactions.</B> You must sign the
certification. You may cross out item 2 of the certification. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>4. Other payments.</B> You must give your correct TIN, but you do not have to sign
the certification unless you have been notified that you have previously given an incorrect TIN. &#147;Other payments&#148; include payments made in the course of the requester&#146;s trade or business for rents, royalties, goods (other than bills
for merchandise), medical and health care services (including payments to corporations), payments to a nonemployee for services, payments made in settlement of payment card and third party network transactions, payments to certain fishing boat crew
members and fishermen, and gross proceeds paid to attorneys (including payments to corporations). </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>5. Mortgage interest paid by you, acquisition or
abandonment of secured property, cancellation of debt, qualified tuition program payments (under section 529), ABLE accounts (under section 529A), IRA, Coverdell ESA, Archer MSA or HSA contributions or distributions, and pension distributions.</B>
You must give your correct TIN, but you do not have to sign the certification. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>What Name and Number To Give the Requester</B> </P>
<P STYLE="font-size:2pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="5" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1.00pt solid #000000; BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt"> <P STYLE="font-size:6pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00pt solid #000000">Grantor trust filing under the Form 1041 Filing Method or the Optional Form 1099 Filing Method 2 (see&nbsp;Regulation section
<FONT STYLE="white-space:nowrap">1.671-4(b)(2)(i)(B))</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE=" BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00pt solid #000000">The trust</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:3pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><SUP STYLE="font-size:85%; vertical-align:top">1</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;List first and circle the name of the person whose number you furnish. If only one
person on a joint account has an SSN, that person&#146;s number must be furnished. </P> <P STYLE="font-size:3pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><SUP
STYLE="font-size:85%; vertical-align:top">2</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Circle the minor&#146;s name and furnish the minor&#146;s SSN. </P> <P STYLE="font-size:3pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><SUP STYLE="font-size:85%; vertical-align:top">3</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;You must show your individual name and you may also enter your business or DBA name on
the &#147;Business name/disregarded entity&#148; name line. You may use either your SSN or EIN (if you have one), but the IRS encourages you to use your SSN. </P> <P STYLE="font-size:3pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><SUP STYLE="font-size:85%; vertical-align:top">4</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;List first and circle the name of the trust, estate, or pension trust. (Do not furnish
the TIN of the personal representative or trustee unless the legal entity itself is not designated in the account title.) Also see <I>Special rules for partnerships</I> earlier. </P>
<P STYLE="font-size:3pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:8pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR style = "page-break-inside:avoid">
<TD WIDTH="6" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><B>*</B></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><B>Note.</B> Grantor also must provide a Form W-9 to trustee of trust. </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Note. </B>If no name is circled when more than
one name is listed, the number will be considered to be that of the first name listed. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Secure Your Tax Records From Identity Theft </B></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">Identity theft occurs when someone uses your personal information such as your name, SSN, or other identifying information, without your permission, to commit fraud or
other crimes. An identity thief may use your SSN to get a job or may file a tax return using your SSN to receive a refund. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">To reduce your risk: </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">&#149; Protect your SSN, </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">&#149; Ensure your employer is protecting your SSN, and </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">&#149; Be careful when choosing a tax preparer. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">If your tax records
are affected by identity theft and you receive a notice from the IRS, respond right away to the name and phone number printed on the IRS notice or letter. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">If your tax records are not currently affected by identity theft but you think you are at risk due to a lost or stolen purse or wallet, questionable
credit card activity or credit report, contact the IRS Identity Theft Hotline at 1-800-908-4490 or submit Form 14039. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">For more information, see Pub.
5027, Identity Theft Information for Taxpayers. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">Victims of identity theft who are experiencing economic harm or a systemic problem, or are seeking
help in resolving tax problems that have not been resolved through normal channels, may be eligible for Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) assistance. You can reach TAS by calling the TAS toll-free case intake line at 1-877-777-4778 or TTY/TDD
1-800-829-4059. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Protect yourself from suspicious emails or phishing schemes. </B>Phishing is the creation and use of email and websites designed to mimic
legitimate business emails and websites. The most common act is sending an email to a user falsely claiming to be an established legitimate enterprise in an attempt to scam the user into surrendering private information that will be used for
identity theft. </P></div><div style="clear:both; height:0pt; font-size:0pt">&nbsp;</div>

</DIV></Center>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


<Center><DIV STYLE="width:8.5in" align="left">

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:7pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="100%"> <P STYLE=" margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt; font-size:7pt; font-family:ARIAL">Form W-9 (Rev. <FONT STYLE="white-space:nowrap">11-2017)</FONT> </P></TD>
<TD> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt; font-size:7pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="right">Page&nbsp;<FONT STYLE="font-size:10pt"><B>6</B></FONT> </P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="line-height:4.0pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:2pt;border-bottom:1.00pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P>
<p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; width:48%;padding-right:0%;padding-bottom:8pt;overflow:hidden;padding-top:3pt">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">The IRS does not initiate contacts with taxpayers via emails. Also, the IRS does not request personal
detailed information through email or ask taxpayers for the PIN numbers, passwords, or similar secret access information for their credit card, bank, or other financial accounts. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">If you receive an unsolicited email claiming to be from the IRS, forward this message to <I>phishing@irs.gov.</I> You may also report misuse of the IRS
name, logo, or other IRS property to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) at 1-800-366-4484. You can forward suspicious emails to the Federal Trade Commission at <I>spam@uce.gov</I> or report them at
<I>www.ftc.gov/complaint.</I> You can contact the FTC at <I>www.ftc.gov/idtheft</I> or 877-IDTHEFT (877-438-4338). If you have been the victim of identity theft, see <I>www.IdentityTheft.gov</I> and Pub. 5027. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:1%; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">Visit <I>www.irs.gov/IdentityTheft</I> to learn more about identity theft and how to reduce your risk.
</P></DIV><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; margin-left:3%; width:49%;padding-right:0%;padding-bottom:8pt;overflow:hidden;padding-top:3pt">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Privacy Act Notice </B></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:8pt; font-family:ARIAL">Section 6109
of the Internal Revenue Code requires you to provide your correct TIN to persons (including federal agencies) who are required to file information returns with the IRS to report interest, dividends, or certain other income paid to you; mortgage
interest you paid; the acquisition or abandonment of secured property; the cancellation of debt; or contributions you made to an IRA, Archer MSA, or HSA. The person collecting this form uses the information on the form to file information returns
with the IRS, reporting the above information. Routine uses of this information include giving it to the Department of Justice for civil and criminal litigation and to cities, states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. commonwealths and possessions
for use in administering their laws. The information also may be disclosed to other countries under a treaty, to federal and state agencies to enforce civil and criminal laws, or to federal law enforcement and intelligence agencies to combat
terrorism. You must provide your TIN whether or not you are required to file a tax return. Under section 3406, payers must generally withhold a percentage of taxable interest, dividend, and certain other payments to a payee who does not give a TIN
to the payer. Certain penalties may also apply for providing false or fraudulent information. </P></div><div style="clear:both; height:0pt; font-size:0pt">&nbsp;</div>

</DIV></Center>

</BODY></HTML>
